reviewTitle: Impressive Sound Quality and User-Friendly Features: Boat Stone 352 Speaker Review
reviewDescription:
The media could not be loaded.
                
            
                
            
        
    
    








  
  
    ¬†I recently had the pleasure of experiencing the Boat Stone 352 Speaker for two days, and I must say, it left a lasting impression. From its crystal-clear sound to its user-friendly features, this portable speaker proved to be a worthy addition to my audio setup.The audio quality of the Boat Stone 352 is simply outstanding. The clarity of the sound was remarkable, allowing me to appreciate the intricacies of my favorite tracks. While the bass wasn't excessively booming, it provided a balanced and enjoyable listening experience, making it perfect for a single room where you can still feel the rhythm and energy of the music.One of the standout features of this speaker is its sound optimization. Boat has done an excellent job in fine-tuning the audio output, ensuring that every note and beat is optimized for maximum enjoyment. Whether I was listening to music or watching a movie, the sound quality was consistently impressive.In terms of battery life, I found the Boat Stone 352 to be quite reliable. With the volume set at around 80%, I could easily enjoy 4 to 5 hours of continuous playback. Additionally, I noticed a convenient power-saving feature. If the speaker remains paired with a device but no music is played for 5 minutes, it automatically powers off, helping to conserve battery life. This thoughtful addition impressed me as it ensures that the speaker doesn't drain unnecessary power when not in use.The overall build quality of the Boat Stone 352 is solid, and the compact design makes it highly portable. It's easy to carry around, allowing me to bring my favorite tunes wherever I go. The Bluetooth connectivity was seamless, ensuring a hassle-free pairing process with my devices.To summarize, the Boat Stone 352 Speaker is a fantastic choice for anyone seeking excellent sound quality and user-friendly features. Its clear audio, balanced bass, and sound optimization make it a pleasure to listen to. The battery life is sufficient for extended listening sessions, and the automatic power-off feature is a welcome addition. If you're in the market for a reliable and compact portable speaker, the Boat Stone 352 is definitely worth considering.

reviewTitle: For the most part, it works fine (IF YOU ARE ON MacOS OR LINUX, BEWARE)
reviewDescription: The speaker sounds pretty good for this price point, to say the least and with a small amount of bass boost, it will reproduce sub 80Hz frequencies satisfactorily. It's not too heavy when you carry it around with a carabiner on your bag when you walk around with it.However, this product has a few problems when supporting Unix-based systems like MacOS and Linux (Windows users may have a better experience for various obvious reasons). Let us start with Linux.IF YOU HAVE A LINUX SYSTEM, STAY AWAY!It does not work with PULSEAUDIO or PIPEWIRE, I TRIED ALL CODECS, SBC, SBC-XQ and HFP (this speaker doesn't support LDAC and aptX for obvious reasons) and the only one that works is HFP, but that is a protocol used for handsfree voice calls, and cannot be used to listen to music, unless you like listening to caller-tune quality audio! This is not a hardware issue either, I tried using my Raspberry Pi with Debian (or Raspberry Pi OS), and I tried using it with Asahi Linux on my Macbook Air. A friend tried it on his Dell G5 with Arch Linux and it does not work.For 95% of all use cases on MacOS, it works fine. But when you fire up certain pieces of software, it ceases to work properly altogether. One example is Schism Tracker (plays Amiga .mod files and other tracker music formats). The speaker refuses to play any audio when the tracker file plays. I tried with another bluetooth headset (JBL Endurance), and it works perfectly.The least Imagine Marketing can do is test their products for compatibility with other operating systems and the way they implement the Bluetooth standard and then list on their product page what OSes it's compatible with. Disappointing.
